# Primify

This program can convert an arbitrary image into a prime. Given an image, it will generate a base-ten number with the same amount of digits as the image has pixels with `9` representing black and `0` representing white. This can be converted back into a greyscale image.

## Usage

1. Open `primify.nb` with Mathematica
2. Replace the placeholder picture of a computer with your desired image (copy-paste or drag-and-drop). See [Image Considerations](#image-considerations) for optimal formatting.
3. Run the preprocessing cells.
4. Run the `Parallel Search` cell. Eventually, this will output a number. When it does, abort the cell (`Evaluation -> Abort Evaluation`).
5. Copy this number into the `myPrime = ` cell.
6. Run the following cells to ensure your image is indeed a prime, and to see how it looks.

The search takes about 20-30 minutes for a 109x109 pixel image on my i7-12650H.

## Image Considerations

- Your image will be converted into grayscale image
- It is recommended that the dimensions of your image be SomePrime x SomePossiblyDifferentPrime. This way, when converting your number into an array of pixels, there is only one reasonable way to do so. Of course, this is purely stylistic; the program will work irrespective of which dimensions are chosen.
- The author has specifically tested 109x109 and 131x97 images. The program generated a prime in approximately 20-40 minutes.
